revision.comment: /* top */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[Open-source software|open source]] (2)
revision.text:
This is a '''list of [[proprietary software|proprietary]] [[source-available software]]''', which has available [[source code]], but is not classified as [[free software]] or [[open-source software]]. In some cases, this type of software is originally sold and released without the [[source code]], and the source code becomes available later. Sometimes, the source code is released under a liberal [[software license]] at its [[End-of-life (product)|end of life]] as [[abandonware]]. This type of software can also have its source code [[Internet leak|leaked]] or [[Reverse engineering|reverse engineered]].
While such software often becomes later [[open source software]] or [[public domain]], also other constructs and [[software license]]s exist, for instance [[shared source]] or [[creative commons]] licenses.<ref>[http://www.rosenlaw.com/pdf-files/Rosen_Ch11.pdf Shared Source, Eventual Source, and Other Licensing Models - Alternatives to Open Source] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308083610/http://www.rosenlaw.com/pdf-files/Rosen_Ch11.pdf |date=8 March 2014 }}, by [[Lawrence Rosen (attorney)|Lawrence Rosen]] (2004)</ref><ref>[http://oreilly.com/openbook/osfreesoft/book/ch05.pdf CHAPTER 5 Non-Open Source Licenses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222055716/http://www.oreilly.com/openbook/osfreesoft/book/ch05.pdf |date=22 December 2014 }}, Understanding Open Source and Free Software Licensing - By Andrew M. St. Laurent, August 2004</ref> If the source code is given out without specified license or [[Public domain software|public domain]] [[waiver]] it has legally to be considered as still proprietary due to the [[Berne Convention]].
For a list of video game software with available source code, see [[List of commercial video games with available source code]]. For specifically formerly [[proprietary software]] which is now free software, see [[List of formerly proprietary software]].

derivative works of Research Unix®1 Editions 8, 9, and 10"''. |- | Chipset and graphics chips drivers and documentation | [[VIA Technologies]] | 200? | 2005/2008 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | GPL | <ref>[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/04/12/via_open_source/ via_open_source] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316024925/https://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/04/12/via_open_source/ |date=16 March 2017 }} (2005)</ref><ref>[http://linux.via.com.tw/support/downloadFiles.action Linux portal] at via.com</ref><ref>[http://www.viatech.com/en/2008/11/via-collaborates-with-open-on-open-source-video-driver/ via-collaborates-with-open-on-open-source-video-driver] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316113332/http://www.viatech.com/en/2008/11/via-collaborates-with-open-on-open-source-video-driver/ |date=16 March 2017 }} (2008)</ref> |- | [[Unrar]] | [[Rarlabs]] | 1995 | 2000 | {{no}} | {{yes}} | {{no}} | own unrar license<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Licensing:Unrar?rd=Licensing/Unrar |title=Licensing:Unrar - FedoraProject |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106195558/https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Licensing%3AUnrar?rd=Licensing%2FUnrar |archivedate=6 January 2015 }}</ref> | Unrar source code was released by [[Eugene Roshal]]/RARlabs sometime in 2000. A GPL fork of older codebase exists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unrarlib.org/license.html |title=Home of unrarlib - UniquE RAR File Library - License |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140713041401/http://www.unrarlib.org/license.html |archivedate=13 July 2014 }}</ref> |- | ''[[Warzone 2100]]'' | [[Pumpkin Studios]]/[[Eidos Interactive]] | March 1999 | December 2004 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} (only movies not)<ref name="forums.wz2100.net">{{cite web|url=http://forums.wz2100.net/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=858 |title=Warzone 2100 Content License |publisher= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106161138/http://forums.wz2100.net/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=858 |archivedate=6 January 2015 }}</ref> | {{yes}} (GPL2+, only movies not)<ref name="forums.wz2100.net"/> | [[GNU General Public License|GPL]]v2 | Video game by [[Eidos Interactive]] |- | [[Watcom C compiler]] | [[Watcom]] | 1988 | 2003 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{no}} | [[Sybase Open Watcom Public License]] | Released as [[Open Watcom]], under a license which is considered free by the OSI<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spdx.org/licenses/|title=SPDX License List|publisher=}}</ref> but not by the FSF. The FSF has problems with the license as it demands more freedom than the GPL by requiring the release of source code also in the case of private use.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html#Watcom |publisher=gnu.org |accessdate=2015-12-23 |title=Various Licenses and Comments about Them - Sybase Open Watcom Public License version 1.0 (#Watcom) |quote=''This is not a free software license. It requires you to publish the source code publicly whenever you "Deploy" the covered software, and "Deploy" is defined to include many kinds of private use.'' |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724023833/https://www.gnu.org/licenses/license-list.html |archivedate=24 July 2010 }}</ref> |- |[[WebOS]] | [[Hewlett-Packard]] |2009 |2012 |{{yes}} |{{yes}} |{{yes}} |[[Apache license]] |Written originally in 2009 by Palm, in December 2011 HP announced it would release the WebOS source code in the near future under an [[open-source license]].<ref name="HpWebOsOpenSource">{{cite web|title=HP to Contribute WebOS to Open Source |url=http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press/2011/111209xa.html |work=Press Release: December 9, 2011 |publisher=Hewlett-Packard |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=10 December 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210120130/http://www.hp.com/hpinfo/newsroom/press/2011/111209xa.html |archivedate=10 December 2011 }}</ref> In August 2012, code specific to the existing devices was released as ''WebOS Community Edition'' (CE), with support for the existing HP hardware.<ref>[https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2012/08/hp-releases-more-open-webos-code-including-system-manager-and-core-apps/ HP releases more Open webOS code, including System Manager and core apps] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161015140000/http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2012/08/hp-releases-more-open-webos-code-including-system-manager-and-core-apps/ |date=15 October 2016 }} on arstechnica.com by Ryan Paul (3 Aug 2012)</ref> |- | [[Windows Live Writer]] | [[Microsoft]] | 2012 | 2015 |{{yes}} |{{yes}} |{{yes}} | [[MIT License]] | An [[Open-source software|open source]] [[Fork (software)|fork]] of Windows Live Writer was released as [[Open Live Writer]] on 9 December 2015.<ref>[https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/12/microsoft-open-sources-live-writer-beloved-but-abandoned-blogging-tool/ Microsoft open-sources Live Writer, beloved but abandoned blogging tool] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612020134/http://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2015/12/microsoft-open-sources-live-writer-beloved-but-abandoned-blogging-tool/ |date=12 June 2016 }} by Peter Bright on [[Ars Technica]] ''"Opening the app means that it'll get some much-needed maintenance."'' (2015)</ref> |- | [[Wintermute Engine]] | Dead:Code Software | 2003 | 2013 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | MIT license |The [[source code]] of the portable Wintermute Lite 2D engine has been released by author Jan Nedoma under a [[MIT License]] on [[Bitbucket]].<ref name="bitbucketrep">[https://bitbucket.org/MnemonicWME/wme1/src/08c8320f21cd02864276da62356d4af05614b3f3/license.txt?at=default license.txt] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223159/https://bitbucket.org/MnemonicWME/wme1/src/08c8320f21cd02864276da62356d4af05614b3f3/license.txt?at=default |date=3 March 2016 }} on bitbucket.org</ref> It is also [[Donationware]], as the author asks for donations for continued development.<ref>[http://dead-code.org/home/index.php/donate/ donate] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170326053458/http://dead-code.org/home/index.php/donate/ |date=26 March 2017 }} on dead-code.org</ref> Also Wintermute 1.x and Wintermute 2 were released under MIT.<ref>[https://bitbucket.org/MnemonicWME/ MnemonicWME] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170328022744/https://bitbucket.org/MnemonicWME/ |date=28 March 2017 }} on bitbucket.org</ref> In 2012 [[ScummVM]] integrated the WME lite engine into their framework.<ref>[http://wiki.scummvm.org/index.php/Wintermute Wintermute] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170618055348/http://wiki.scummvm.org/index.php/Wintermute |date=18 June 2017 }} on scummvm.org</ref> |- | [[Xenko]] |[[Silicon Studio]] | 2014 | 2014 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | GPLv3 |Xenko, formerly known as Paradox, is a [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]] [[game engine]] with an asset pipeline and a cross-platform runtime supporting iOS, Android, Windows UWP, Linux, and PlayStation4. It was made [[free and open-source software]] in October 2014.<ref>[http://xenko.com/blog/new-version-open-sourcing/ new-version-open-sourcing] on xenko.com (October 2014)</ref> Xenko beta version 1.8x was then released finally out of beta in February 2017.<ref>[http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2017-02-24-silicon-studio-releasing-xenko-engine 2017-02-24-silicon-studio-releasing-xenko-engine] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314154210/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2017-02-24-silicon-studio-releasing-xenko-engine |date=14 March 2017 }} on gamesindustry.biz</ref> |- | [[Xerox Alto]] |[[Computer History Museum]] | 1975 | 2014 | {{no}} | {{yes}} | {{no}} | own non-commercial license | On 21 October 2014, Xerox Alto's [[source code]] and other resources were released from the [[Computer History Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerhistory.org/atchm/xerox-alto-source-code/ |quote=''With the permission of the Palo Alto Research Center, the Computer History Museum is pleased to make available, for non-commercial use only, snapshots of Alto source code, executables, documentation, font files, and other files from 1975 to 1987.'' |title=Xerox Alto Source Code - The roots of the modern personal computer |publisher=[[Computer History Museum]] |first=Paul |last=McJones |work=Software Gems: The Computer History Museum Historical Source Code Series |date=2014-10-21 |accessdate=2015-01-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150102201034/http://www.computerhistory.org/atchm/xerox-alto-source-code/ |archivedate=2 January 2015 }}</ref> |- | [[XMind]] | XMind Ltd. | 2007 | 2008 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | [[Eclipse Public License]] and LGPL | [[Mindmapping]] software based on the [[Eclipse RCP]] |- | [[ZFS]] | [[Sun Microsystems]] | 200? | 2005 | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | {{yes}} | [[CDDL]] | The innovative next-generation [[file system]] was released by [[Sun Microsystems]] under an open-source license in 2005.<ref>[https://arstechnica.com/uncategorized/2005/11/5595-2/ Sun opens ZFS source code] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628133244/http://arstechnica.com/uncategorized/2005/11/5595-2/ |date=28 June 2016 }} on [[Ars Technica]] by Ryan Paul (17 Nov 2005)</ref> Due to an potential [[License compatibility|license incompatibility]] of the GPL with the CDDL it wasn't directly integrated in linux (until 2016 when Ubuntu included it), but in the BSDs or MacOS due to their permissive licensed kernel. After the later owner Oracle didn't released after version 28, the community forked to [[OpenZFS]].<ref>[http://open-zfs.org/wiki/FAQ FAQ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160103105216/http://open-zfs.org/wiki/FAQ |date=3 January 2016 }} on open-zfs.org</ref> |}

[[Image:Loggia dei Lanzi 2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|General view.]] The '''Loggia dei Lanzi''', also called the '''Loggia della Signoria''', is a building on a corner of the [[Piazza della Signoria]] in [[Florence]], [[Italy]], adjoining the [[Uffizi|Uffizi Gallery]]. It consists of wide arches open to the street. The arches rest on clustered pilasters with [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] capitals. The wide arches appealed so much to the Florentines that [[Michelangelo]] proposed that they should be continued all around the Piazza della Signoria.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}} Sometimes erroneously referred to as ''[[Loggia]] dell' [[Andrea Orcagna|Orcagna]]''{{cite book | first=Guido | last=Zucconi | year= 1995| title=Florence: An Architectural Guide | publisher=Arsenale Editrice srl | location=San Giovanni Lupatoto, Vr, Italy | isbn=88-7743-147-4}} because it was once thought to be designed by that artist, it was built between 1376 and 1382 by [[Benci di Cione]] and [[Simone di Francesco Talenti]],{{cite book | year=2007 | title=loggia | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}} possibly following a design by [[Jacopo di Sione]], to house the assemblies of the people and hold public ceremonies, such as the swearing into office of the Gonfaloniers and the Priors. Simone Talenti is also well-known from his contributions to the churches [[Orsanmichele]] and San Carlo. The vivacious construction of the Loggia is in stark contrast with the severe architecture of the Palazzo Vecchio. It is effectively an open-air sculpture gallery of antique and [[Renaissance art]]. The name ''Loggia dei Lanzi'' dates back to the reign of Grand Duke [[Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Cosimo I]], when it was used to house his formidable [[landsknecht]]s (In Italian: "Lanzichenecchi", corrupted to ''Lanzi''), or German mercenary pikemen. After the construction of the Uffizi at the rear of the Loggia, the Loggia's roof was modified by [[Bernardo Buontalenti]] and became a terrace from which the [[Medici]] princes could watch ceremonies in the piazza. ==Description== === Architectural setting === [[Image:Firenze-piazza signoria statue02.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''[[Menelaus supporting the body of Patroclus]]'', a much-restored Roman sculpture]] On the façade of the Loggia, below the [[parapet]], are [[trefoil]]s with allegorical figures of the four [[cardinal virtues]] (Fortitude, Temperance, Justice and Prudence) by [[Agnolo Gaddi]].{{cite book | year=2007 | title=Gaddi, Agnolo | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}} Their blue enamelled background is the work of Leonardo, a monk, while the golden stars were painted by Lorenzo de' Bicci. The vault, composed of semicircles, was done by the Florentine [[Antonio de' Pucci]]. On the steps of the Loggia are the ''[[Medici lions]]''; two [[Marzocco]]s{{citation needed|reason=The Marzocco seems to be a sitting lion with a escutcheon.|date=January 2016}}, marble statues of lions, heraldic symbols of Florence; that on the right is from Roman times and the one on the left was sculpted by [[Flaminio Vacca]] in 1598. It was originally placed in the [[Villa Medici]] in Rome, but found its final place in the Loggia in 1789.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} On the side of the Loggia, there is a [[Latin language|Latin]] inscription from 1750 commemorating the change of the Florentine calendar in 1749 to bring it into line with the Roman calendar. The Florentine calendar began on 25 March instead of 1 January. The other inscription from 1893 records the Florentines who distinguished themselves during the annexation of [[Milan]] (1865), [[Venice]] (1866) and Rome (1871) to the kingdom of Italy. {| align=left ! colspan="4" style="background:#ECECEC; "|'''Facade Trefoils with Four Virtues''' |- |[[image:Fortitude at Loggia dei Lanzi.jpg|100px]] |[[image:VirtueLoggiaLanziB.jpg|100px]] |[[image:VirtueLoggiaLanziC.jpg|100px]] |[[image:VirtueLoggiaLanziD.jpg|100px]] |- | style="background:#ECECEC; "|
''Fortitude''
| style="background:#ECECEC;"|
''Temperance''
| style="background:#ECECEC;"|
''Justice''
| style="background:#ECECEC;"|
''Prudence''
|} {{wide image|Loggia dei Lanzi 360 view small.jpg|600px|360° view from inside}} ===Statuary=== [[Image:Firenze.Loggia.Perseus01.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Benvenuto Cellini's ''[[Perseus with the Head of Medusa]]''.]] [[Image:Giambologna herculesenesso.jpg|thumb|left|250px|''[[Hercules]] and [[Nessus (mythology)|Nessus]]'' (1599), Florence]] [[File:Lion of Loggia de' Lanzi right.JPG|thumb|200px|One of the ''[[Medici lions]]''.]] Underneath the bay on the far left is the [[bronze statue]] of ''[[Perseus]]'' by [[Benvenuto Cellini]].{{cite book | year=2007 | title=Florence | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}} It shows the mythical Greek hero holding his sword in his right hand and holding up the [[Medusa]]'s severed head in his left. The well-proportioned muscular body of Perseus stands poised on the right leg. Perseus is reflecting and he seems to be frightened by his same action. Blood is gushing from the head and the neck of the dead Medusa. The richly decorated marble pedestal, also by Cellini, shows four graceful bronze statuettes of [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]], [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercurius]], [[Minerva]] and [[Danaë]]. The bas-relief on the pedestal, representing ''Perseus freeing Andromeda'', is a copy of the one in [[Bargello]]. [[Benvenuto Cellini]] worked almost ten years on this bronze (1545-1554). His wax design was immediately approved by [[Cosimo I de' Medici]]. He met numerous difficulties which, according to his autobiography, almost brought him to the brink of death. The casting of this bronze statue was several times unsuccessful. When attempting again, the melting furnace got overheated, spoiling the casting of the bronze. Cellini gave orders to feed the furnace with his household furniture and finally with about 200 pewter dishes and plates, and his pots and pans. This caused the bronze to flow again. After the bronze had cooled, the statue was finished, except for three toes on the right foot. These were added later. [[Image:Giambologna sabine.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''The Rape of the Sabine Women''.]] On the far right is the [[Mannerism|manneristic]] group ''[[Rape of the Sabine Women (Giambologna)|Rape of the Sabine Women]]'' by the Flemish artist Jean de Boulogne, better known by his Italianized name [[Giambologna]].{{cite book | year=2007 | title=Giambologna | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}} This impressive work was made from one imperfect block of white marble, the largest block ever transported to Florence. The goccia model is now in the Galleria dell' Academia.[http://www.friendsofflorence.org/English/Friends/press.htm Copy of the rape of the Sabine Woman] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219175733/http://www.friendsofflorence.org/English/Friends/press.htm |date=19 December 2007 }} Giambologna wanted to create a composition with the ''figura serpentina'', an upward snakelike spiral movement to be examined from all sides. This is the first group representing more than a single figure in European sculptural history to be conceived without a dominant viewpoint. It can be equally admired from all sides. The marble pedestal, also by Giambologna, represents bronze bas-reliefs with the same theme. This marble and bronze group is in the Loggia since 1583. Nearby is Giambologna's less celebrated [[marble sculpture]] ''Hercules beating the Centaur Nessus'' (1599) and placed here in 1841 from the Canto de' Carnesecchi. It was sculpted from one solid block of white marble with the help of Pietro Francavilla The group ''[[Menelaus supporting the body of Patroclus]]'', discovered in [[Rome]] stood originally at the southern end of the [[Ponte Vecchio]]. There is another version of this much-restored Roman marble in the [[Palazzo Pitti]]. It is an ancient Roman sculpture from the [[Flavius|Flavian]] era, copied from a [[Pergamum|Hellenistic Pergamene]] original of the mid third century BC. This marble group was discovered in Rome. It has undergone restorations by Ludovico Salvetti, to a model by [[Pietro Tacca]] (1640) and by Stefano Ricci (about 1830). The group ''The Rape of [[Polyxena]]'', is a fine diagonal sculpture by [[Pio Fedi]] from 1865. [[Image:PolyxenaFedi.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''The Rape of Polyxena'']] On the back of the Loggia are five marble female statues (three are identified as Matidia, Marciana and Agrippina Minor),[https://books.google.com/books?id=yfmN96E_VHgC&pg=PA114 Giovanna Giusti Galardi, The Statues of the Loggia Della Signoria in Florence] [[Sabine]]s and a statue of a barbarian prisoner [[Thusnelda]] from Roman times from the era of [[Trajan]] to [[Hadrian]]. They were discovered in Rome in 1541. The statues had been in the Medici villa at Rome since 1584 and were brought here by Pietro Leopoldo in 1789. They all have significant, modern restorations. The [[Feldherrnhalle]] in [[Munich]], commissioned by King [[Ludwig I of Bavaria]] to honor the tradition of his military, was modelled after the Loggia dei Lanzi. ==References == {{reflist|33em}} == External links == {{Commonscat-inline}} {{Coord|43|46|9.13|N|11|15|20.37|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Florence landmarks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loggia Dei Lanzi}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1382]] [[Category:Loggias in Florence]] [[Category:Renaissance architecture in Florence]] [[Category:Uffizi]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Florence]]

page.title: McKinlay Hendry Ltd v Tonkin & Taylor Ltd

revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Music Maker Relief Foundation |image = |formation = 1994 |status = Foundation |purpose = To Help The True Pioneers of American Music |headquarters = [[Hillsborough, NC]] |leader_name = Tim Duffy |website = {{url|http://www.musicmaker.org/}} }}
'''Music Maker Relief Foundation''' is an [[United States|American]] [[non-profit organization|non-profit]], based in [[Hillsborough, North Carolina]]. Music Maker Relief Foundation was founded in 1994 by Tim and Denise Duffy to "help the true pioneers and forgotten heroes of Southern music gain recognition and meet their day-to-day needs. Music Maker presents these musical traditions to the world so American culture will flourish and be preserved for future generations."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.musicmaker.org/mission/ |title=The Music Maker Mission - Music Maker Relief Foundation |publisher=Musicmaker.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001021745/http://www.musicmaker.org/mission/ |archivedate=2006-10-01 |df= }}</ref>
==History== ===Early years=== In 1989, while completing his studies for a master's degree in [[Folklore]] at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], Tim Duffy was documenting [[blues]] musician James "Guitar Slim" Stephens for the university's Southern Folklife Collection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/d/Duffy,Timothy.html |title=Timothy Duffy Collection, 1990-2004 |publisher=Lib.unc.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> Stephens's health was in decline, and shortly before his death, he advised Duffy to locate a musician named [[Guitar Gabriel]].
After his graduation, Duffy began working as a substitute teacher at a middle school in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem]], hearing an assortment of folkloric tales about Guitar Gabriel from students, until one student volunteered that Gabriel was her neighbor, living in the [[public housing|government housing projects]] of Winston-Salem. That evening, Duffy followed the student's directions to a "drink house" in the neighborhood, where he met Gabriel's nephew, Hawkeye, who took him to meet Gabriel. Duffy forged a close friendship with Gabriel, and the two began recording and performing under the name Guitar Gabriel & Brothers in the Kitchen, releasing the album ''Do You Know What it Means to Have a Friend?'' (also known as ''Toot Blues'') on their own Karibu label in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/guitgfrm.htm|title=Guitar Gabriel|publisher=Wirz.de|accessdate=2012-10-16}}</ref>
Gabriel had been inactive in the music industry since the 1970 release of his album ''My South, My Blues'' (as Nyles Jones) on the Gemini label.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Nyles-Jones-My-South-My-Blues/release/2604538 |title=Nyles Jones - My South My Blues (Vinyl, LP) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> He had received no royalties {{citation needed|date=August 2016}} and was impoverished. He required almost daily assistance from Duffy, who provided transportation to medical appointments, money, and food for Gabriel and his wife. Through Gabriel, Tim and Denise Duffy made field recordings of other local blues musicians, such as Captain Luke, Macavine Hayes, Mr. Q., and Willa Mae Buckner.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} They lived in poor conditions and needed regular assistance.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} Duffy thought their culture was slipping away unnoticed by the music industry.
Tim Duffy's father, Allen Duffy, a lawyer, had represented and won a case for audio pioneer [[Mark Levinson (audio equipment designer)|Mark Levinson]], allowing him to continue working in the [[High fidelity|hi-fi]] industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bluesart.at/NeueSeiten/TIM+DUFFY.html |title=Tim Duffy And Music Maker |publisher=Bluesart.at |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> Levinson heard about Tim Duffy's field recordings, some reminiscent of the work of [[John Lomax|John]] and [[Alan Lomax]], and invited Duffy to visit his stereo showroom in New York. After hearing the recordings, as well as the stories of the many destitute musicians, Levinson offered to remaster the tapes, which became an eight-artist CD anthology of traditional North Carolina blues entitled ''A Living Past''. Levinson became a crusader for the cause, and solicited funds and industry connections from his friends and colleagues, which, in 1994, resulted in the incorporation of the Music Maker Relief Foundation.<ref>from an interview of Tim Duffy on the [http://americanamusicshow.com/episode219 Americana Music Show #219], published November 10, 2014</ref>
===1995–present=== In 1995, Tim Duffy met [[Eric Clapton]] in a [[Manhattan]] bistro, sharing some of his field recordings, as well as the philosophy and goals of the foundation, after which Clapton became a supporter, introducing artists such as [[B.B. King]], [[Pete Townshend]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], [[Ron Wood]], [[Lou Reed]] and [[Rosanne Cash]], all of whom donated to the Music Maker Relief Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/musicmakers/mm5100.html |title=American Blues-Music Maker Relief Foundation: Music Maker Article |publisher=Ibiblio.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> Duffy was invited to the Los Angeles studio where B.B. King's album ''[[Deuces Wild (B. B. King album)|Deuces Wild]]'' was recorded and where he met [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], who contributed to the foundation's growth and success.
By 1996, after receiving several sizable donations, Music Maker Relief Foundation had established the Musician Sustenance, Musical Development, and Cultural Access Programs, which provide food, monetary assistance, transportation to doctor's appointments and to pick up medications, home repairs (in some cases, extremely poor living conditions have warranted the relocation of the musician), performance bookings in professional venues, such as the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]] and [[Carnegie Hall]], as well as European tours and music festivals worldwide. The success of which is due, in large part, to Taj Mahal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://swampland.com/articles/view/title:tim_duffy_music_maker_relief_foundation |title=Tim Duffy: Music Maker Relief Foundation |publisher=Swampland |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> who by 1997 had become an advisory board member, artistic consultant, contributor, and co-producer for many of the artists' records. Taj Mahal headlined blues festivals in support of Music Maker, was instrumental in securing advertising in mainstream print media, as well as the creation of the "Fishin' Blues Tournament", which raises funds for the foundation. Over the next several years, many new donors and contributors were involved, allowing Duffy to expand the roster of the label, and to release over one hundred albums, the proceeds of which the artists keep, in their entirety. Many of the label's artists have been documented in the collaborative work of artists [[Harvey Pekar]] and [[Gary Dumm]], who have contributed artwork since 2003,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicmaker.org/comics/ |title=Comics - Music Maker Relief Foundation |publisher=Musicmaker.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> and whose work was featured in a 2010 calendar, created as a fundraiser for Music Maker Relief Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicmaker.org/articles_post/harvey/ |title=Harvey Pekar/Gary Dumm 2010 Calendar in the News - Articles - Music Maker Relief Foundation |publisher=Musicmaker.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref>
In 2006, Tim Duffy saw the [[Carolina Chocolate Drops]] performing at the Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival of Music and Dance in [[Silk Hope, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wake Zine|title=Feature {{!}} Carolina Chocolate Drops|url=http://wakezine.com/carolina-chocolate-drops/|website=Wakezine.com|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> Duffy signed a management deal with the group and released their debut record, ''Dona Got a Ramblin' Mind'' on the Music Maker Label. During Duffy's time as manager the Carolina Chocolate Drops won a [[Grammy Award]] in 2010 for Best Traditional Folk Album with their first album on [[Nonesuch Records]], ''Genuine Negro Jig''.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last1=Weston|first1=Keith|title=Grammys: Steep Canyon Rangers Win Best Bluegrass Album, Avett Brothers & Chocolate Drops Miss|url=http://wunc.org/post/grammys-steep-canyon-rangers-win-best-bluegrass-album-avett-brothers-chocolate-drops-miss|website=Wunc.org|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> The Chocolate Drops second release with Nonesuch, ''Leaving Eden'' was nominated for a Grammy.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
In 2014, the Music Maker Relief Foundation celebrated its 20th anniversary with an exhibit of 28 photographs of Music Maker artists. The exhibit was previewed at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts. A double-disc compilation album and 144-page photo book is also set to be released in honor of the foundation's anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mazor|first1=Barry|title=Giving Them a Hand The Music Maker Foundation Celebrates 20 Years.|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/giving-music-makers-a-hand-1407362559|website=Nytimes.com|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref>
On October 27, 2014 [[PBS NewsHour]] aired segment on the Music Maker Relief Foundation, showing [[William R. Ferris]] say, "They provide a model for what our nation should be doing. The New Deal under FDR did this for the entire nation, and Tim Duffy thankfully is doing it for the community of blues artists."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brown|first1=Jeffrey|title=Music Maker eases the blues for down-and-out artists|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/music-maker-eases-blues-artists/|website=Pbs.org|publisher=Public Broadcasting Service|accessdate=10 March 2015}}</ref>
==Artists== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Little Pink Anderson]] * Harvey Arnold * [[Etta Baker]] * [[Robert Belfour]] * [[Adolphus Bell]] * The Branchettes * [[Skeeter Brandon]] * Essie Mae Brooks * [[Tommy Brown (singer)|Tommy Brown]] * [[Cora Mae Bryant]] * [[Precious Bryant]] * Willa Mae Buckner * [[Randy Burns]] * Dr. G. B. Burt * Lil' Joe Burton * David Butler * [[Carolina Chocolate Drops]] * Pat "Mother Blues" Cohen * Robert Lee Coleman * The Como Mamas * George Conner * George Daniels * [[James B. Davis (musician)|James B. Davis]] * [[Ardie Dean]] * [[Ernie K-Doe]] * [[Drink Small]] * Paul Duffy * [[Frank Edwards (blues musician)|Mr. Frank Edwards]] * [[Pura Fé]] * [[Cool John Ferguson]] * [[Robert Finley (musician)|Robert Finley]] * Dom Flemons * [[Benton Flippen]] * Cora Fluker * Sam Frazier, Jr. * Preston Fulp * [[Guitar Gabriel]] * [[Lee Gates]] * Elder James Goins * Boo Hanks * Macavine Hayes * [[Big Boy Henry]] * [[George Higgs]] * [[Algia Mae Hinton]] * Carl Hodges * [[John Dee Holeman]] * Big Ron Hunter * [[Ironing Board Sam]] * David Johnson * Elder Anderson Johnson * Todd Jones * Kever's Long House Singers * [[Little Freddie King]] * Pernell King * Sonny Boy King * [[Willie King]] * Clyde Langford * Guitar Lightnin' Lee * Lucille Lindsay * Captain Luke * [[Bishop Dready Manning]] * Marie Manning * William Maxwell * [[Jerry McCain|Jerry "Boogie" McCain]] * [[Dave McGraw & Mandy Fer]] * Rufus McKenzie * Nora Milner * W.C. Minger IV * Mudcat * [[Chicago Bob Nelson]] * [[Sonny Boy Nelson]] * Bubba Norwood * [[Jack Owens (blues singer)|Jack Owens]] * [[Neal Pattman]] * [[Pinetop Perkins]] * Abe Reid * Jahue Rorie * Carl Rutherford * Cueselle Settle (Mr. Q.) * Larry Shores * [[Patrick Sky]] * Slewfoot * Alabama Slim * Albert Smith * Sol * [[Cootie Stark]] * James "Guitar Slim" Stephens * Samuel Turner Stevens * Sweet Betty * Robert Thomas * Eddie Tigner * Reverend Perry Tillis * [[Othar Turner]] * Tad Walters * J. W. Warren * [[Beverly Watkins]] * [[Lightnin' Wells]] * Pete Whicher * Whistlin' Britches * [[Albert White (musician)|Albert White]] * Pat Wilder * Ernie Williams {{div col end}}
==Discography== {{Incomplete list|date=May 2017}} ===Albums=== * 1977 : ''This Stuff Just Kills Me'' by [[Jerry McCain]] with [[John Primer]] and [[Johnnie Johnson (musician)|Johnnie Johnson]] * 1999 : ''Railroad Bill'' by [[Etta Baker]] (MM7) * 1999 : ''Sugar Man'' by [[Cootie Stark]] (MM8) * 1999 : ''Back in Business'' by [[Beverly Watkins]] * 2000 : ''Rain in Your Life'' by Essie Mae Brooks (MM15) * 2001 : ''Cool John Ferguson'' by [[Cool John Ferguson]] (MM18) * 2001 : ''Unplugged'' by [[Jerry McCain]] (MM21) * 2002 : ''Songs from the Roots of America'' ( I & II ) * 2002 : ''Ragged but Right'' by [[Lightnin' Wells]] * 2002 : ''Carolina Bluesman'' by [[Little Pink Anderson]] (MM24) * 2002 : ''Cool Yule'' by [[Cool John Ferguson]] (MM29) * 2003 : ''Guitar Heaven'' by [[Cool John Ferguson]] (MM34) * 2003 : ''Boogie is My Name'' by [[Jerry McCain]] (MM34) * 2004 : ''High Steppin' Momma'' by Clyde Langford (MM45) * 2004 : ''Follow Your Heart's Desire'' by [[Pura Fé]] (MM48) * 2004 : ''Musicmakers with Taj Mahal'' (MM49) * 2004 : ''Etta Baker with Taj Mahal'' (MM50) * 2005 : ''The Last & Lost Blues Survivors'' (Dixiefrog) * 2005 : ''Tarboro Blues'' by [[George Higgs]] * #REDIRECT [[Multiracial]]
[[Category:Multiracial affairs]]

[[File:North Greenwood.png|alt=Rear view of North Greenwood Library|thumb|Rear view of North Greenwood Library]] The '''North Greenwood Library''' is a public library that is part of the [[Clearwater Public Library System|Clearwater Library System]] which, in turn, is part of the [[Pinellas Public Library Cooperative]]. Located at 905 N Martin Luther King Jr. Ave, its current Branch Manager is Christa Smith.
== Services == The North Greenwood Library's patrons can check out a variety of materials including books, magazines, DVDs, Blu-rays, video games, and a ukulele kit. There is a computer lab with free internet access and free Wi-Fi throughout the library. For non library members, there are two 15 minute express computers. The library offers paid copy and scanning services. It does not have a fax machine. The library has one community room that is used for programs and can be reserved through the online calendar. The newly renovated children's area has Lego tables and coloring areas as well as coloring materials. There is a high definition television that kids can use to watch [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|G or PG rated]] DVDs and Blu-rays with librarian permission. All books are free to be read inside the library without needing to be checked out. With a library card issued from North Greenwood and other Clearwater Libraries, patrons have access to online applications and materials such as [[OverDrive, Inc.|Overdrive]], [http://www.pronunciator.com/ Pronunciator], Zinio, 3M, and [[Hoopla (digital media service)|Hoopla]].
== History == During the 1940s, the black community felt that they should have a library for their children and the future generations. The City Commission agreed to fund a library as long as the community found a building and librarian willing to work there. The library, simply referred to as the "Negro Library", first opened on March 15, 1950 on the corner of Pennsylvania and Cedar Street in a rented building space. [[Christine Wigfall Morris]] was the librarian who first opened the doors of the library and was the first black Librarian to work in Clearwater, Fl.<ref>Clearwater Library History http://www.myclearwaterlibrary.com/learn/historical-information/clearwater-library-history</ref>
The library, loved by both the community and "Miss Chris", outgrew its rented space so a building was officially built for the collection on Palmetto street. The new building, named the Northeast Library and designed by Eugene Beach, was meant to be run by a single librarian— [[Christine Wigfall Morris|Christine Morris]]. It opened in September, 1962 with a collection of 15,000 books. Christine Morris worked tirelessly to keep the library open acting as not only a librarian, but also janitor and community counselor.<ref>Kathryn Johnston. "Christine Wigfall Morris" Women of Library History. http://womenoflibraryhistory.tumblr.com/post/115029361252/christine-wigfall-morris</ref><ref>Castillo, P. (2011). LONGTIME LIBRARIAN LOOKS BACK; Christine Morris, a trailblazer in Clearwater, writes a book about 'the legacy of my family and the community.'. The St. Petersburg Times (St. Petersburg, FL).</ref> It was not until 1983, after Morris' retirement, that the library received its current name of North Greenwood Library.
In 1970 the "Edward Allen Henry Jr. Special Collection on Negro Culture and History" was added to the library. In 2002 the special collection's name was changed to "The [[Christine Wigfall Morris]] African American Collection" in honor of her decades of work and dedication to the library and the community. In an interview, [[Christine Wigfall Morris|Christine Morris]] commented that the community believed the whole library should be named in her honor but the city said she would have to be deceased in order for it to be allowed. She preferred to be alive and see the collection named after herself than to be dead and not see the whole building named.<ref>Morris, C. W. (2011). NEWSMAKER: CHRISTINE WIGFALL MORRIS. American Libraries, (3/4). 18.</ref><ref>Samuels, Adrienne P. "Library honors its supporters." St. Petersburg Times [St. Petersburg, FL] 9 Aug. 2002: 1. Business Insights: Essentials. Web. 15 Apr. 2017.</ref>
North Greenwood's current location at the corner of N. Martin Luther King Jr. Ave and Palmetto St was built in 2002. Its grand opening was January 18, 2003.<ref>"Library Closing To Relocate, Begin New Chapter." Tampa Tribune [Tampa, FL] 29 Dec. 2002: 3. Business Insights: Essentials. Web. 15 Apr. 2017. http://bi.galegroup.com/essentials/article/GALE%7CA95918845/a9a67c5ad806896c74ed3016b6b35452?u=tamp44898</ref>
2009 proved to be a worrisome year for North Greenwood Library, as well as East Library, as budget cuts threatened to close the facility and move the collection to a space inside the North Greenwood Recreation center. In protest of closing the library, the NAACP and local ministers staged marches to save the library.<ref>Brassfield, Mike. "LITTLE LIBRARY IN PERIL; North Greenwood's branch may close, its collection pared and fit into a rec center." St. Petersburg Times [St. Petersburg, FL] 11 June 2009: 1. Business Insights: Essentials. Web. 15 Apr. 2017.</ref>After two months of debate, protests, and voting, it was decided that taxes would be raised and the libraries would stay open but with reduced hours. While many people disagreed with the tax increase, one counsel member remarked how surprised she was that so many of her constituents were willing to accept the tax increase if it meant the libraries stayed open.<ref>Brassfield, Mike. "COUNCIL OKAYS TAX INCREASE; The vote will keep the East Branch and North Greenwood libraries from closing." St. Petersburg Times [St. Petersburg, FL] 19 Sept. 2009: 1. Business Insights: Essentials. Web. 15 Apr. 2017.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

[[Category:1950 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:African-American history of Florida]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Clearwater, Florida]] [[Category:Libraries in Florida]] [[Category:Public libraries in Florida]] [[Category:Segregation]]

revision.comment: "leaked by" Al Jazeera to "leaked to" (and published by) Al Jazeera—"leaking" is done by people who have access to sensitive material, not by the media organization which publishes it
revision.text:
{{For|the [[nonfiction]] book of the same name|Doreen Ingrams}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Israel-Palestinian Peace Process}}
The '''Palestine Papers''' is a collection of confidential documents about the [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process]] [[news leak|leaked]] to [[Al Jazeera]], which published them between 23 and 26 January 2011. Nearly 1,700 of documents from the office of the main [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO]] negotiator, Sa'eb Erekat, and his team have been published, dating from 1999 to 2010.<ref>{{cite news |title=Introducing The Palestine Papers |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/palestinepapers/2011/01/201112214310263628.html |date=23 January 2011 |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=FAQ: The Palestine Papers |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/palestinepapers/2011/01/2011123114726552723.html |date=23 January 2011 |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=23 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=story_behind>''Guardian'', 24 January 2011, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/23/story-behind-leaked-palestine-papers "The story behind the Palestine papers"]</ref>
Al Jazeera and ''[[The Guardian]]'' say they have authenticated the documents, and a media adviser to [[Israel]]i Prime Minister [[Ehud Olmert]] also affirmed their authenticity. Leaders of the [[Palestinian Authority]] have complained about the way the documents were presented by Al Jazeera.
== Background == The Palestine Papers uncover documents about the negotiations between the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] (PLO), the only recognized representative of the Palestinian people, and Israel from 1999 to 2010. The negotiations in 1993 that led to the [[Oslo Accords]] were the first direct negotiations between the parties. The following "peace process" focussed on the formation of the [[Palestinian Authority]] (PA) and the territory it would govern. The PA, however, represents only the local people in the [[Occupied Palestinian Territories]], not the Palestinians in the [[diaspora]].
In 2011, when the Papers were published, the negotiations were in a deadlock after the refusal in September 2010 of the [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] government to extend the freeze of [[Israeli settlement|settlements building]] over ten months. Ziyad Clot, the until now only identified source, felt frustrated about the fact that the great majority of the Palestinian people, the [[Palestinian right of return|refugees]], being one of the "remaining issues" in the "peace process", were not properly represented.<ref name=pp_blew_the_whistle />
== Sources of the Papers == The documents were obtained by [[Al Jazeera]] and shared in advance of publication with ''[[The Guardian]]'' in an effort to ensure the wider availability of their content. ''The Guardian'' has authenticated the bulk of the Papers independently, but has not sought or been given access to the sources of the documents. Al Jazeera, which published the Papers on their website, has [[Redaction|redacted]] minimal parts of the papers to protect their sources' identities.<ref>{{cite news |title=Palestine papers: Editor's note |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/23/palestine-papers-editors-note |date=23 January 2011 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=23 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
=== NSU === Most of the documents are from the Palestinian negotiation support unit (NSU). The NSU was the [[Palestine Liberation Organization|PLO's]] main technical and legal advice organ in the peace negotiations, set up in 1999 and headed by [[Saeb Erekat]].<ref name=story_behind /> Gershon Baskin, codirector of [[Israel/Palestine Center for Research and Information|Israel/Palestinian Center for Research]], said, "I'm 100 percent sure that it's a former disgruntled employed" member of the Negotiations Support Unit headed by Palestinian chief negotiator [[Saeb Erekat]]. Israel's Channel 10 news show also named the source of the leak as a former member of the NSU.<ref>{{cite news |title=Possible source of Palestine papers leak |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0125/Possible-source-of-Palestine-papers-leak |date=25 January 2011 |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
=== Clayton Swisher === On 27 January 2011, following Al Jazeera's broadcast of the Palestine Papers, Saeb Erekat appeared on Al Jazeera Arabic, condemning the publication. He accused Al Jazeera journalist [[Clayton Swisher]], who delivered the disclosure of the Palestine Papers, of being a CIA agent and of working for the NSU. He also said that former British intelligence officer [[Alastair Crooke]] was involved.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011127163052761490.html Erekat condemns Palestine Papers]. Al Jazeera, 27 January 2011 (video)</ref> In [[Ma'an News Agency]], Erekat later admitted Clayton Swisher neither worked for the Palestinians nor the US intelligence agency.<ref>[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=356993 Palestinian negotiator backtracks on CIA charge]. George Hale, Ma'an News Agency, 4 February 2011</ref>
A few weeks after the publication of the Palestine Papers, on 11 February 2011, Erekat resigned as Chief PLO Negotiator, citing the release of the papers and due to an internal Palestinian investigation that suggested the Palestine Papers leak had come from a source inside Erekat's office.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011212135152355248.html Erekat quits over Palestine Papers]. Al Jazeera, 13 February 2011</ref><ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jlNVedQZfU1Y6iuRI0EiYMsc2ZfQ?docId=CNG.34b0a7cfb441605b61894f84b5a9eda2.b71 Palestinian election plan runs into Hamas obstacle]. Nasser Abu Bakr, AFP, 12 February 2011</ref> As of February 2017, however, he was still holding the function of Chief Palestinian Negotiator.<ref>{{cite web|title=Erekat to remain chief PA negotiator|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/225091|website=Arutz Sheva|accessdate=14 June 2017}}</ref>
In his book ''The Palestine Papers: The End of the Road?'', Swisher confirmed account, as he wrote, "In the fall of 2010, I traveled the world meeting with US, Israeli, and Palestinian Authority officials who had no idea that I held in my possession the secret records of their negotiations".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Palestine-Papers-End-Road/dp/1843913534 |title=The Palestine Papers: The End of the Road?|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|website=Amazon.com |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> A complaint filed by Erekat and the PLO against Al Jazeera and Clayton Swisher on grounds of unfairness was wholly dismissed in a 19-page ruling released in October 2011.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ofcom Broadcast Bulletin |url=http://stakeholders.ofcom.org.uk/binaries/enforcement/broadcast-bulletins/obb191/obb191.pdf |date=10 October 2011 |work=Ofcom |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ofcom's ruling on the Palestine papers offers hope to the Middle East |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/oct/10/ofcom-al-jazeera-palestine-papers |date=10 October 2011 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref>
=== Ziyad Clot === In a 14 May 2011 op-ed article in the ''Guardian'', Ziyad Clot, a French lawyer of Palestinian descent and a former adviser for the NSU involved in 2008 Annapolis negotiations exposed himself as one of the sources of the leaks. In the ''Guardian'' article, Clot said that the so-called peace process was "an inequitable and destructive political process which had been based on the assumption that the Palestinians could in effect negotiate their rights and achieve self-determination while enduring the hardship of the Israeli occupation". He also said that "the "peace negotiations" were a deceptive farce whereby biased terms were unilaterally imposed by Israel and systematically endorsed by the US and EU". Clot emphasized that "these negotiations excluded for the most part the great majority of the Palestinian people: the seven million Palestinian refugees". He felt "that the PLO, given its structure, was not in a position to represent all Palestinian rights and interests". Clot resigned from the NSU after he witnessed the killing of more than 1,400 Palestinians in Gaza during the [[Gaza War (2008–09)|Gaza War]]. After he resigned, he believed he had a duty to inform the public. In the Guardian article, he also stated: "In full conscience, and acting independently, I later agreed to share some information with al-Jazeera specifically with regard to the fate of Palestinian refugee rights in the 2008 talks. Other sources did the same, although I am unaware of their identity."<ref name=pp_blew_the_whistle>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/may/14/blew-the-whistle-about-palestine?CMP=twt_g Why I blew the whistle about Palestine], ''The Guardian'', 14 May 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/french-lawyer-reveals-himself-as-palestine-papers-source-1.361679 French lawyer reveals himself as 'Palestine papers' source]. ''Haaretz'', 14 May 2011</ref>
== The documents ==
=== Character of the documents === The ''Palestine Papers'' include many [[minutes]] of bilateral meetings between Israel and the Palestinians and with the USA as well as minutes of joint trilateral meetings. They also include other documents, such as memos, [[email]]s, letters, strategy papers, a matrix of positions<ref name=positions_matrix>[http://transparency.aljazeera.net/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/201218233256500873.html Current P/I positions reflecting discussion up to June 30, 2008]</ref> and even maps of possible land swaps<ref name=landswaps>[http://transparency.aljazeera.net/files/2648.PDF Meeting Minutes On Borders], 4 May 2008. On [http://transparency.aljazeera.net/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/20121823285937752.html]; [http://transparency.aljazeera.net/files/4736.PDF Summary of Olmert’s “Package” Offer to Abu Mazen], 31 August 2008. On [http://transparency.aljazeera.net/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/20121821046718794.html]</ref> and [[Presentation program|power point presentations]]<ref>[http://thepalestinepapers.com/files/2590.pdf Water for a Viable Palestinian State], 17 May 2008. On [http://thepalestinepapers.com/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/201218232625296694.html]</ref><ref>[http://thepalestinepapers.com/files/4440.PDF Palestinian-Israeli Conflict: Challenges to a Negotiated Solution], 1 February 2009. On [http://thepalestinepapers.com/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/201218205458750797.html]</ref>
There were published 1,684 total documents, including: * 275 sets of meeting minutes; * 690 internal emails; * 153 reports and studies; * 134 sets of talking points and prep notes for meetings; * 64 draft agreements; * 54 maps, charts and graphs; * and 51 "non-papers".
[[Akiva Eldar]], writing in ''[[Haaretz]]'', said that the documents are more important than those released by Wikileaks because they deal with current issues regarding permanent borders in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.<ref>Akiva Eldar, [http://www.haaretz.com/opinion/the-palestine-papers-al-jazeera-trumps-wikileaks-1.338875 The Palestine papers: Al-Jazeera trumps WikiLeaks], ''[[Haaretz]]'', 24 January 2011.</ref>
=== Settlements === At a meeting in November 2007, [[Tzipi Livni]] told [[Ahmed Qurei]] that "I understand the sentiments of the Palestinians when they see the settlements being built. The meaning from the Palestinian perspective is that Israel takes more land, that the Palestinian state will be impossible, the Israel policy is to take more and more land day after day and that at the end of the day we'll say that it is impossible, we already have the land and cannot create the state".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2011/feb/12/corrections-clarifications?INTCMP=SRCH |location=London |work=The Guardian |title=Corrections and clarifications |date=12 February 2011}}</ref>
According to the documents, in a meeting with Livni in Jerusalem, Qurei proposed that Israel annex all settlements along the border except for the large cities and towns of [[Giv'at Ze'ev]], [[Ma'ale Adumim]], [[Ariel (city)|Ariel]], and [[Efrat]].<ref name=globeandmail>Patrick Martin, ''The Globe and Mail'', 23 August 2012, [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/israel-rejected-historic-concessions-palestine-papers-reveal/article580377/?page=all Israel rejected historic concessions, 'Palestine Papers' reveal]</ref> Livni rejected Qurei's demands that Israel cede these settlements. Qurei suggested to Livni that these settlements be placed under Palestinian sovereignty, but Livni told him "you know this is not realistic". [[Condoleezza Rice]] similarly told Qurei that "I don't think that any Israeli leader is going to cede Ma'ale Adumim", to which Qurei replied "or any Palestinian". Rice then told him "Then you won't have a state!"<ref name=biggest_Yerushalayim>Al Jazeera − Palestine Papers, 23 January 2011, [http://www.aljazeera.com/palestinepapers/2011/01/2011122112512844113.html "The biggest Yerushalayim"]</ref>
=== Napkin map === "Napkin map" is a colloquial name for a Palestinian sketch made by Palestinian Authority President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] on a napkin, of a map with land swap proposals shown to him by then Prime Minister [[Ehud Olmert]] during peace negotiations in mid-2008. According to Al Jazeera, Abbas was not allowed to keep the unofficial map, so he sketched it by hand. During the first of several meetings, the Palestinian Authority proposed a land swap, offering Israel the opportunity to annex all of the Israeli settlements in East Jerusalem in return for land concessions by Israel. Olmert, however, offered no concessions in return but an even more aggressive land swap.<ref name=pp_napkinmap_revealed>Al Jazeera – Palestine Papers, [http://english.aljazeera.net/palestinepapers/2011/01/2011122114239940577.html The "napkin map" revealed] The maps: [http://transparency.aljazeera.net/files/4736.pdf]</ref>
In Prime Minister Olmert's own proposal, Israel would annex 6.3% <ref name=rd_hamakor>{{cite web |url=http://www.thetower.org/2580-breaking-abbas-admits-for-the-first-time-that-he-turned-down-peace-offer-in-2008/ |title=Hamakor: Raviv Drucker interview of Ehud Olmert and Mahmoud Abbas |last=Drucker |first=Raviv |date=17 November 2015 |publisher=[[Channel 10 News]]}}</ref> of the West Bank. The land in Olmert's map included the four settlements of [[Gush Etzion]] (with [[Efrat]]), [[Ma'ale Adumim]], [[Giv'at Ze'ev]], and [[Ariel (city)|Ariel]], in addition to all settlements in East Jerusalem ([[Har Homa]]). In exchange for those concessions by the Palestinian Authority, Olmert offered 5.8% <ref name=rd_hamakor /> of Israeli land as part of the swap. The land offered consisted of lightly populated farmland, which would be divided between the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. When Mahmoud Abbas asked to keep a copy of the map for further consideration, Ehud Olmert refused to comply. Mahmoud Abbas was forced to sketch Ehud Olmert's map by hand on a napkin to have a copy for further consideration.<ref name=pp_Olmerts_offer>Al Jazeera – Palestine Papers, [http://transparency.aljazeera.net/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/20121821046718794.html ''Summary of Ehud Olmert’s “Package” Offer to Mahmoud Abbas – August 31, 2008'']</ref> This map was then later referred to as the ''Napkin map''.<ref name=pp_napkinmap_revealed />
The third and final meeting occurred on 16 September 2008. It was during this time that Ehud Olmert was nearing the end of his political career. At the time, Olmert was under police investigation for alleged corruption that had occurred while he was Mayor of Jerusalem, and as a result of the accusations was not planning on running again. During the final meeting, Mahmoud Abbas was prepared by the Negotiation Support Unit (NSU) to clarify many questions regarding Ehud Olmert's peace plan in which Abbas was quoted as asking questions such as "How do you see it addressing our interests, especially as Ariel, Maale Adumim, Givat Zeev, Har Homa and Efrat clearly prejudice contiguity, water aquifers, and the viability of Palestine?" as well as others about the value of the land that they would receive in such a swap in terms of value and size.<ref name=pp_napkinmap_revealed />
The Negotiation Support Unit (NSU) also insisted that Prime Minister Olmert provide them with a copy of the map, which was again denied. In the end, however, Mahmoud Abbas asked for a few days to consider the offer. A day after this meeting, Olmert resigned and [[Tzipi Livni]] stepped in as Acting Prime Minister, with [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] being elected shortly afterward. Palestinian negotiators said Abbas had forgotten another appointment and postponed the next meeting. Netanyahu thought Olmert had made too many concessions and refused to continue from where the last round of negotiations had left off, preferring to restart the negotiations from the beginning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/01/30/goodspeed-analysis-a-palestine-that-might-have-been/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: A Palestine that might have been |last=Goodspeed |first=Peter |date=30 January 2011 |work=[[National Post]] |accessdate=20 June 2012 }}</ref>
=== Jerusalem === According to one of the documents, the Palestinian Authority was prepared to concede most [[Israeli settlements]] in [[East Jerusalem]], as well as the [[Armenian Quarter]], with the exception of [[Har Homa]]. The [[Temple Mount]] would be temporarily administrated by a joint body consisting of the Palestinian Authority, Israel, [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[Saudi Arabia]], and the [[United States]] until a permanent solution was reached.<ref name=biggest_Yerushalayim />
At the meeting in Jerusalem in November 2007, Tzipi Livni became visibly angry when asked about the demographic composition of the future Israeli state. She was quoted as saying, "Israel the state of the Jewish people—and I would like to emphasize the meaning of 'its people' is the Jewish people—with Jerusalem the united and undivided capital of Israel and of the Jewish people for 3,007 years". The Palestinians team then protested her position on Jerusalem. She responded by saying "Now I have to say, before we continue, in order to continue we have to put out Jerusalem from your statement and from our place. We have enough differences, without putting another one out there". <ref name=PP_131107>{{cite web|title=The Palestine Papers: Meeting Minutes: 8th Negotiation Team Meeting|url=http://www.ajtransparency.com/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/20121823740234656.html|work=Al Jazeera Transparency Unit|publisher=Al Jazeera Media Network|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=13 November 2007}}</ref>
=== Security === The minutes of the trilateral meeting on 26 August 2008 reveal that Israel not only demands a "demilitarized" Palestinian state, but also wants to keep control over borders, Jordan Valley and airspace, after withdrawal of the Israeli forces from the West Bank, for reasons of security. [[Tzipi Livni]]: "In the Jordan Valley – what will be between Palestine and Jordan. EWS. [Early Warning Stations] ... the I is that we will have something on the crossings, borders, etc ... The idea is to withdraw, but to keep a presence, not close to the situation today, on the EWS, on passages ..."<ref name=PP_260808>Al Jazeera – Palestine Papers, [http://thepalestinepapers.com/files/3242.PDF Meeting Summary, 26 August 2008], second part, pp. 18–19; on [http://thepalestinepapers.com/en/projects/thepalestinepapers/201218203227453537.html]</ref>
=== Refugees === Yankie Galenty, a media adviser for [[Ehud Olmert]], affirmed the complete authenticity of the documents in an interview. In regards to refugees, he stated that "Olmert, from day one, did not deceive Abu Mazen and told him that Israel will not allow the return of refugees and not one refugee will return to the land of Israel."<ref>[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/4739/World/Region/Olmert-adviser-says-AlJazeera-leaks--correct.aspx Olmert adviser says Al-Jazeera leaks 100% correct], ''Al-Ahram'', 24 January 2011</ref>
Other officials in the Israeli government asked for a limited right of return numbering between five and ten thousand, out of a total of five million refugees, who would be carefully picked by Israel and allowed to stay under "humanitarian conditions".
US Secretary of State [[Condoleezza Rice]] proposed settling Palestinians refugees in [[Argentina]] and [[Chile]] as an alternative to letting them return to former homes in Israel and the occupied territories during a meeting.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/24/condoleezza-rice-palestinian-refugees-south-america |location=London |work=The Guardian |first=Rory |last=Carroll |title=Condoleezza Rice: send Palestinian refugees to South America |date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
In her memoirs, [[Condoleezza Rice]] wrote that Olmert initially proposed that Israel accept 5,000 Palestinians refugees. Abbas rejected the offer, saying, "I can't tell four million Palestinians that only 5,000 of them can go home".<ref name="Rice">{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=243917 |title=Rice reveals concessions in 2008 peace talks |last=Stoil |first=Rebecca Anna |date=11 January 2011 |work=[[Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=20 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919025443/http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=243917 |archivedate=19 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> According to the second night of the Al-Jazeera broadcast, Israelis and Palestinians eventually agreed that Israel would accept 10,000 refugees.<ref name="gave up">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/24/papers-palestinian-leaders-refugees-fight?intcmp=239 |location=London |work=The Guardian |first1=Ian |last1=Black |first2=Seumas |last2=Milne |title=Papers reveal how Palestinian leaders gave up fight over refugees |date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
== Reactions ==
=== Palestinian Authority === Palestinian President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] said the leaked documents deliberately confuse Israeli and Palestinian positions, and that he had kept the [[Arab League]] updated on all details of the negotiations with [[Israel]].<ref name=alja24 /> Chief Palestinian negotiator [[Saeb Erekat]] said the leaks were "a pack of lies", containing mistakes and inaccuracies and that his words were taken out of context and he had been misquoted.<ref name=alja24>{{cite news |title=PA negotiators reject leaked report |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011123234940952149.html |date=24 January 2011 |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=24 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Palestinians question 'offers' leaked by al-Jazeera |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12263671 |date=24 January 2011 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=24 January 2011}}</ref> Erekat said that the "Palestinian Authority would never give up any of our rights. If we did indeed offer Israel the Jewish and Armenian Quarters of Jerusalem, and the biggest Yerushalayim as they claim, then why did Israel not sign a final status agreement? Is it not strange that we would offer all these concessions which Israel demands, yet there is still no peace deal?"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12263671 |publisher=BBC News |title=Palestinians attack al-Jazeera 'distorted' talks leaks |date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
[[Yasser Abed Rabbo]], giving the PA's first official response, accused ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' and the Government of [[Qatar]] of attacking the Palestinian Authority, having a hostile attitude towards the PA since the days of former president [[Yasser Arafat]].<ref>[http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/4721/World/Region/PA-hits-back-at-Qatar%E2%80%99s-Amir.aspx PA hits back at Qatar’s Amir], ''Al-Ahram'', 24 January 2011</ref> Abed Rabbo was quoted saying that the Al-Jazeera leaks are "a distortion of the truth".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/24/palestine-papers-distortion-truth-reaction |location=London |work=The Guardian |first1=Ian |last1=Black |first2=Seumas |last2=Milne |first3=Harriet |last3=Sherwood |title=Palestine papers are distortion of truth, say Palestinian officials |date=24 January 2011}}</ref> Abed Rabbo accused the [[Emir of Qatar]], Sheikh [[Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani]], of giving Al Jazeera the "green light" to start the campaign, and called on the Emir to "extend the climate of transparency in his own state and reveal his true relations with Israel and [[Iran]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Mahmoud Abbas: Palestine Papers "fraudulent disinformation campaign"|url=http://www.vancouverite.com/2011/01/25/mahmoud-abbas-palestine-papers-fraudulent-disinformation-campaign/|work=Vancouverite|accessdate=19 June 2012|author=Yehonathan Tommer|date=25 January 2011}}</ref>
[[Mahmoud al-Zahar]], a senior [[Hamas]] official in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]], stated that the [[Palestinian Authority]] officials should be ashamed of themselves.<ref name=alja24 />
[[Ahmed Qurei]], former [[Prime Minister of the Palestinian Authority]] and chief Palestinian negotiator in the 2008 talks, said that "many parts of the documents were fabricated, as part of the incitement against the [[Palestinian Authority]] and the Palestinian leadership".<ref name=alja24 />
[[Nasser Gawi]], a lead organizer for demonstrations in the Jerusalem neighborhood of [[Sheikh Jarrah]], where he had been recently evicted by Israeli settlers from his home, was quoted as saying "Erekat must have become more Zionist than Zionist. He has no mandate to give up Sheikh Jarrah or an inch of Palestine."<ref>{{cite web|title=Palestinian map of dividing Jerusalem 'out of touch with reality', says cartographer|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/palestinian-map-of-dividing-jerusalem-out-of-touch-with-reality-says-cartographer-1.338995|work=Haaretz|accessdate=19 June 2012|author=Nir Hasson|date=25 January 2011}}</ref>
=== Israel === [[Israeli Foreign Minister]] [[Avigdor Lieberman]] said that "even the most left-wing government of Olmert and Livni did not manage to reach a peace agreement, despite the many concessions." He also promoted his [[Lieberman Plan|plan]] for peace, which would allocate 45% to 50% of the [[West Bank]] for the creation of a Palestinian state.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-leaked-palestinian-papers-prove-interim-deal-is-only-option-1.338872 Lieberman: Leaked Palestinian papers prove interim deal is only option], Haaretz, 24 January 2011</ref>
Livni said that "the [peace] process did not fail and was not exhausted. It did not end, but was not allowed to ripen until an agreement was reached because of elections in Israel and this government's choice not to continue the negotiations."<ref>{{cite web|title=Livni: 'Palestine Papers' show peace process is not over|url=http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=205042|work=Jerusaem Post|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=24 January 2011}}</ref>
== See also == * [[United States diplomatic cables leak]], also known as Cablegate * [[Iraq War documents leak]], also known as the Iraqi War Logs * [[Afghan War documents leak]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://thepalestinepapers.com/Services/Search/default.aspx Search the Palestine Papers] on Al Jazeera's English Transparency Unit * [http://english.aljazeera.net/palestinepapers/ The Palestine Papers] by [[Al Jazeera English]] * [https://www.theguardian.com/world/palestine-papers The Palestine Papers] by ''[[The Guardian]]'' * [http://www.therealnews.com/t2/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=33&Itemid=74&jumival=672 The Palestine Papers] by ''[[The Real News]]'' * [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/arabs/PalPaperstoc.html The Palestine Papers] by the Jewish Virtual Library * [[Rashid Khalidi]]: [http://www.democracynow.org/2011/1/24/rashid_khalidi_leaked_palestine_papers_underscore Leaked "Palestine Papers" Underscore Weakness of Palestinian Authority] – video report by ''[[Democracy Now!]]'' * [http://gulfnews.com/news/region/palestinian-territories/palestinian-negotiators-say-leaked-papers-real-1.753201 Palestinian negotiators say leaked papers real] by Abbas Al Lawati of ''[[Gulf News]]''
